Title: The Nucleus of a Multiprogramming System
AuthorList: Per Brinch Hansen. Communications of the ACM, 13:4, April 1970.
Description: The ﬁrst paper to suggest that the OS, or kernel, should be a minimal and ﬂexible substrate for building customized operating systems; this theme is revisited throughout OS research history.

Title: Introduction and Overview of the Multics System
AuthorList: F. J. Corbato, V. A. Vyssotsky. Fall Joint Computer Conference, 1965.
Description: A great early Multics paper. Here is the great quote about time sharing: The impetus for time-sharing ﬁrst arose from professional programmers because of their constant frustration in debugging programs at batch processing installations. Thus, the original goal was to time-share computers to allow simultaneous access by several persons while giving to each of them the illusion of having the whole machine at his disposal.”

Title: Programming Semantics for Multiprogrammed Computations
AuthorList: Jack B. Dennis, Earl C. Van Horn. Communications of the ACM, Volume 9, Number 3, March 1966.
Description: An early paper (but not the ﬁrst) on multiprogramming.

Title: Man-Computer Symbiosis
AuthorList: J. C. R. Licklider. IRE Transactions on Human Factors in Electronics, HFE-1:1, March 1960.
Description: A funky paper about how computers and people are going to enter into a symbiotic age; clearly well ahead of its time but a fascinating read nonetheless.

Title: Time-Sharing Computer Systems
AuthorList: J. McCarthy. Management and the Computer of the Future, MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 1962.
Description: Probably McCarthy’s earliest recorded paper on time sharing. In another paper [M83], he claims to have been thinking of the idea since 1957. McCarthy left the systems area and went on to become a giant in Artiﬁcial Intelligence at Stanford, including the creation of the LISP programming language. See McCarthy’s home page for more info: http://www-formal.stanford.edu/jmc/

Title: A Time-Sharing Debugging System for a Small Computer
AuthorList: J. McCarthy, S. Boilen, E. Fredkin, J. C. R. Licklider. AFIPS ’63 (Spring), New York, NY, May 1963.
Description: A great early example of a system that swapped program memory to the drum” when the program wasn’t running, and then back into core” memory when it was about to be run.

Title: Reminiscences on the History of Time Sharing
Description: A terriﬁc historical note on where the idea of time-sharing might have come fzshortm, including some doubts towards those who cite Strachey’s work [S59] as the by pioneering work in this area..

Title: Valgrind: A Framework for Heavyweight Dynamic Binary Instrumentation
AuthorList: N. Nethercote, J. Seward. PLDI 2007, San Diego, California, June 2007.
Description: Valgrind is a lifesaver of a program for those who use unsafe languages like C. Read this paper to learn about its very cool binary instrumentation techniques – it’s really quite impressive.

Title: Mach: A System Software kernel
AuthorList: R. Rashid, D. Julin, D. Orr, R. Sanzi, R. Baron, A. Forin, D. Golub, M. Jones. COMPCON ’89, February 1989.
Description: Although not the ﬁrst project on microkernels per se, the Mach project at CMU was well-known and inﬂuential; it still lives today deep in the bowels of Mac OS X.

Title: Time Sharing in Large Fast Computers
AuthorList: C. Strachey. Proceedings of the International Conference on Information Processing, UNESCO, June 1959.
Description: One of the earliest references on time sharing.

Title: Improving the Reliability of Commodity Operating Systems
AuthorList: M. M. Swift, B. N. Bershad, H. M. Levy. SOSP ’03.
Description: The ﬁrst paper to show how microkernel-like thinking can improve operating system reliability.
